title: Einangsteinen (Einang stone)
description: The Einang stone is located in Gardbergfeltet, a historical site in Oppland, Norway, holding over 550 burial mounds and over 900 discoveries from Roman Iron Age and Viking Age. The Einang stone is believed to date back to around 300 AD, and for a long time was the oldest known runic stone from northwestern Europe.
explanationAfter: Excellent! As explained by Kristel Zilmer on Twitter (see sources): Moltke's reading - still commonly accepted - is: …daga-(t)(i)R runo faihido. He suggested that the start could be: [Ek Go]dagastiR rūnō faihidō, «I, GodagastiR, painted (wrote) the rune (i.e. the runic inscription)”. The singular rūnō can refer to the overall runic message.

title: Svingerudsteinen (Svingerud Stone)
description: In early 2023, this stone was announced to be the oldest known runic inscription to date. It was found in a cremation ground, in Hole near Tyrifjorden, Eastern Norway, by University of Oslo researchers. The inscriptions are dated between 1 and 250 AD. The stone itself is a 31x32 cm block of reddish-brown Ringerike sandstone.
explanationAfter: Great answer! The inscription, consisting of thin, shallow runes, is transliterated as "Idiberug". According to Kristel Zilmer, professor at Oslo's Museum of Cultural History: this could be name of a woman Idibera or a kin named Idiberung.

title: Bergen stick B 149
description: The stick has an inscription on both sides, consisting of mixed long- and short-twig Younger Futhark runes. The first side says: ᚴᛦᛆ : ᛌᛅᚼᛁᚱ : ᛆᛐᚦᚢ : ᚴᛆᚴ : ᚼᛅᛁᛉ.
explanationAfter: Yes! That is the famous inscription which translates to "Gyða segir at þú gakk heim" - "Gyða tells you to go home"!

title: Grumpan bracteate Vg 207
description: Grumpan bracteate was found in Sweden and is dated to ca. 500-550 AD. It is kept in the Historiska Museet in Stockholm.
explanationAfter: Correct! This bracteate depicts the division of Elder Futhark row into 3 equal parts.

img_credit: Own photo, taken in Mariefred, Sweden
title: Gripsholm stone Sö 178
description: A rune stone with inscription from the 11th century.
runes: ᚼᛅᚴᚢᛚᚠᚱ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᛅᚢᛚᚠᚱ x ᚦᛅᛁᛦ x ᛚᛅᛏᚢ x ᚱᛅᛁᛁᛋᛅ x ᛋᛏᛅᛁᚾᛅ x ᛒᛅᚦᛅ x ᛅᛏ x ᛒᚱᚬᚦᚢᚱ x ᛋᛁᚾ x ᚴᛁᛏᛁᛚᛘᚢᛏ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᛒᚱᚬ x ᛁᚠᛏᛁᛦ x ᛋᚬᛘᚢ x ᛘᚬᚦᚢᚱ x ᛋᛁᚾᛅ x ᛁᛅ x ᛁᚱᚢᚾᛁ x ᛁᛁᚢᚴ x ᛒᚱᚬᚦᛁᛦ x ᚼᛁᚾᛅᛦ
explanationAfter: Correct. The stone reads: "Hälgulv (?) and Oulv they had this stone raised in memory of their brother, Kätilmund, and built a bridge in memory of Soma, their mother. But Brune (?), her brother, carved (the runes)"
sources: A plaque next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet

title: Gripsholm stone Sö 179
description: The Gripsholm Stone - which can to this day be visited near the Gripsholm Castle not far from Stockholm - is one of the "Ingvarr stones". This group of stones is dated soon after 1041, when the Icelandic annals record the death of Yngvarr the Far-Travelled in the south. Note how the inscriber forgot one word and added it later!
explanationAfter: Correct. The last part (from the word inserted later) runs: "Þæiʀ foru drængila, fjarri at gulli, auk austarla ærni gafu. Dou sunnarla, a Særklandi" -- "They went manfully, far after gold, and in the east gave [food] to the eagle [i.e. despatched enemies in battle]. They died in the south, in Særkland." (translation credit to Michael P. Barnes, p. 77 from Runes: A Handbook)
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 77-8, 81, 139, 169)

title: Kylver stone G 88
description: The Kylver stone originates from the Baltic island of Gotland. It is one of eleven known inscriptions of the older futhark row, dated to 5th and 6th centuries (only 4 of these 11 give the complete rune row order).
explanationAfter: Two things to note about the Kylver stone: 1) there is no division of the run row into the ættir - groups of eight - unlike for example the Grumpan bracteate; 2) the runes at positions 13-4 (ᛈ, ᛇ) and 23-4 (ᛞ, ᛟ) are given in the opposite order than usually.
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 16-19)

title: Jelling stone of Harald Bluetooth
description: A rune-stone with political themes from north-eastern Jutland. King Haraldr claims on it to have made himself master of all Denmark and of Norway. These are among the earliest occurrences of the names "Denmark" and "Norway". Thanks to the  political references, Jelling 2 stone can be fairly reliably dated to around 970-980s.
explanationAfter: The translation to be found in Barnes' book is as follows: "King Haraldr ordered [people] to make these monuments after GormR, his father and after Þorvi, his mother. That Haraldr who won for himself all Denmark, and Norway, and made the Danes Christian." ("Haraldr kunungR bað gørva kumbl þøsi aft Gorm, faður sin, ok aft Þórvi, moður sina. Sa Haraldr æs sæR vann Danmork alla ok Norvæg ok dani gærði kristna.")
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 73-4)

title: Ramsundberget carving Sö 101
description: The Ramsund carving is located in Södermanland, Sweden. The carving is almost 5m wide, making it the biggest known rune carving. It is unusual, since the carving is made in a flat rock, not in a standing stone.
explanationAfter: Good answer! The runes are believed to translate to "Sigriðr gærði bro þasi, moðiR Alriks, dottiR Orms, for salu HolmgæiRs, faður SigrøðaR, boanda sins." -- "Sigríðr, Alríkr's mother, Ormr's daughter, made this bridge for the soul of Holmgeirr, father of Sigrøðr, her husbandman".
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 84)

title: Kjølevik stone N KJ75
description: The Kjølevik stone is dated to 5th century and was found in Rogaland, south+western Norway.
explanationAfter: Old Norse translation of the inscription is believed to be "Haðulaikaz. Ek Hagustaldaz hlaiwiðdo magu minino" -- "Haðulaikaz. I Hagustaldaz buried my son". Haðulaikaz is a man's name consisting of elements "battle" ahnd "play".
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 30)

title: Burseryd baptismal font
description: This is 13th century baptismal font from Burseryd church in Småland, Sweden.
explanationAfter: Yes! Translation: "Arinbjorn gjørði mik. Vitkunder prester skref mik. Ok hær skal um stund standa" -- "Arinbjorn made me. Vitkunder the priest wrote me. And here I shall stand for a while". Interesting detail is the use of [th] instead of [þ] in the spelling of "gørthi". Note there are some bind runes, which in this exercise were split due to limitations of Unicode.
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 102-3)

title: Maughold I stone
description: This runestone is dated to 1150-1199 and was found in the Maughold parish in the Isle of Man.
explanationAfter: Yes! According to Scandinavian Runic-text Database (see sources), the inferred transliteration is "(i)(u)an + brist + raisti + þasir + runur +¶ [f]uþor(k)(h)niastbml +". The translation to Old Norse is "Jóan prestr reisti þessar rúnar. <fuþorkhniastbml>" and to English: "Jóan the priest carved these runes. fuþorkhniastbml"

title: Ågedal bracteate N IK1
description: Little is known about this bracteate. It was found in southern Norway and contains inscriptions in Older Futhark, though with inconsistent direction of carving. It is made of gold and is dated before early 8th century.
explanationAfter: That's a correct transliteration of the intelligible symbols. Uppsala University website makes the following attempt at translation to Old Norse: "Þiz æje, i-rioð, i yhli-afl haha! Lið tiaðe elli aiga i tahe". English: "The slave-woman, rosy-cheeked, full of yule-power (=intoxicated), may lead the horse to the pasture! It became apparent that the old one had a retinue in the tún (=his own homestead)".

title: Assasin's Creed Valhalla loading screen
description: This text is looped twice around the game logo in the loading screen of Assasin's Creed Valhalla.
runes: ᛏᛅᚢᛦ ᚠᛁ ᛏᛅᚢᛁᛅ ᚠᚱᚬᛏᛦ ᛏᛅᚢᛦ ᛋᛁᛅᛚᚠᛦ ᛁᛏ ᛋᛅᛘᛅ ᛁᚴ ᚢᛅᛁᛏ ᛅᛁᚾ ᛅᛏ ᛅᛚᛏᚱᛁ ᛏᛅᚢᛦ ᛏᚢᛘᛦ ᚢᛒ ᛏᛅᚢᚦᛅᚾ ᚼᚢᛅᚱᚾ
explanationAfter: This text is an excerpt from Havamal - stanza 77 to be precise: "deyr fé, deyja frændr, deyr sjalfr it sama, ek veit einn, at aldrei deyr: dómr um dauðan hvern". In Carolyne Larringtone's translation: "Cattle die, kinsmen die, the self must also die; I know one thing which never dies; the reputation of each dead man."

title: An excerpt from the Codex Runicus
description: Codex runicus is a vellum manuscript from c. 1300, containing early Danish law texts, in particular the Scanian Law (Skånske lov).
explanationAfter: Correct! this medieval manuscript reads "Særær man annær man mæþæn kunung ær innæn lændæs bøtæ fore sar sum loh æræ ok kunungi firitiuhu mark ok hinum ær sar fik firitiuhu mark fore friþbrut". In English: "If a man wounds another man while the king is the province he shall pay a fine for the wound in accordance with the law, and 40 marks to the king and 40 marks for breach of the peace to the one who was wounded".

title: Rök runestone, side A (fragment) Ög 136
description: The Rök runestone from Östergötland, Sweden, is dated to 9th century. It contains inscriptions in 3 different runic ortographies: short-twig runes, older Fuþark and numerical cipher. The scholars have long debated the meaning (and even reading order!) of the inscription. For one recent interpretation, binding it to poems Vafþrúðnismál and Völuspá, see Holmberg et al., 2020 (linked in the sources). For the exercise below, we use the very beginning of the inscription. Note that due to limitations of Runic Unicode block, I had to use ᛅ and ᛙ as substitutes for two other short-twig runes.
explanationAfter: Excellent! This translates as: "Aft Vāmōð stãnda rūnaʀ þāʀ. Æn Varinn fāði, faðiʀ, aft faigiãn sunu.", or in English: "After Vāmōðʀ stand these runes. And Varinn, the father, made them after thedeath-doomed son".
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 83)

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands.
description: The runestick was found during archeological excavations in Durhúsi in Eiði. Runologically, the inscription is dated to 900-1200 AD. Archeological observations point to the elder part of this period.
title: Eiði runestick
explanationAfter: Indeed, the stick contains first 13 rune characters of short-twig Younger Fuþark, which were used in North Western areas, including Faroes.
sources: Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands.
title: Sandavágur rune-stone
description: This is the most magnificent rune-stone inscription found in the Faroes. The stone was found by chance, at the abandoned ancient settlement í Eingjartoftum in Sandavágur in 1917. You can see this to this day in Sandavágur church. The runes are of the younger Swedo-Norwegian type.
explanationAfter: Good! The translation provided by Tjóðsavnið is: "1. þorkæl onondarsun 2. austmaþrafruha 3. lande bygþe þe(n) 4. a saþ fyst". In English: "Torkil Onundarson from Rogaland was the first to settle this place."
sources: Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands

img_credit: Own photo, taken at Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands.
title: Sørvágur wooden box
description: This box orignates from the Sørvágur village in the Vágar island.
explanationAfter: The latin alphabet has been carved with runes, supplemented by the date ANNO 1695. G. I. S. below stands for G(utti) J(oens) S(on).
sources: Tjóðsavnið - the National Museum of Faroe Islands

title: Adventure Time: runic banner from "Five More Short Graybles"
description: This is a banner from an episode "Five More Short Graybles" written in Older Futhark.
explanationAfter: Indeed, that's a guitar repair shop! Note how they used the thorn rune wrongly, as "p" instead of "th".

title: Adventure Time: a cup from "Video Makers"
description: A message on a cup from which Finn pours drinks in the "Video Makers" episode. It appears to be in the Anglo-Saxon runic system.
explanationAfter: Correct! Note the wrong usage of the thorn rune as "p" instead of "th". The authors intended to spell "Cup of many ale".

title: Adventure Time: a sword from "Web Weirdos"
description: This magic sword appears in an episode "Web weirdos".
explanationAfter: Yes! The sword says "I am a skeleton I wish I had skin".

title: Adventure Time: a staff from "Storytelling"
description: This secret message appears on the staff of the Forest Wizard in the "Storytelling" episode when he bashes Finn on the head with it. The image is flipped horizontally.
explanationAfter: Yes, it spells FACE.

title: Adventure Time: a sword from "Morituri Te Salutamus"
description: A sword that occurs in the episode "Morituri Te Salutamus"
explanationAfter: Indeed, the runic message says "To fight is to live". While the use of Uruz rune for "v" is historically common, the choice of ᚹ for "h" is more surprising.

title: Oseberg inscription N 137
description: An inscription on a wooden runic stave found at the famous Oseberg ship in Tønsberg, Vestfold, Norway. Dated to the viking period, more specifically early 9th century. Einar Selvik can often be seen wearing a shirt with this inscription - for example, at the Midgardsblot festival, which takes place close to this historic place.
explanationAfter: That's a correct transliteration. Interpretation of this inscription is unclear, with some theories saying: "little man knows" or "you idiot".

title: Dalängen runsten i Lidingö
description: A runestone standing by the road in Lidingö. One of the two present on the island. It was found in 19th century and it has been standing in its current place since 1943.
runes: ᚴᚬᚱᛁ x ᛅᚢᚴ x ᛁᛅᚴᛚᛏᚱ x ᛅᚢ … ᛁᚱ ᛫ ᛒᛁᛁᚱᚾ ᛫ ᚠᛅᚦᚢᚱ ᛫ ᛋᛁᚾ ᛫ ᚴᚢᚦ ᛫ …
explanationAfter: The remaining part of the stone can be read as "Kore and Ingjald and ... after Björn, their father. God ...". It seems to follow a standard formula, helping us fill the gaps: "Kore and Ingjald raised this stone after Björn, their father. God help...".
sources: Info table next to the stone, provided by Stockholms Läns Museum and Lidingö Stad

title: Bjärby stone Ö 36
description: A beautiful 11-century runestone standing by the side of the road in Bjärby in eastern Öland, Sweden.
explanationAfter: Correct! Swedish translation provided onsite: "Härfrid och Vidbjörn läto resa stenen efter Fastul sin fader. Siglaug lät resa efter sin make. Han är begraven i kyrkan." In English that would be: "Harfrid and Vidbjorn had this stone raised after their father Fastul. Siglaug had it raised after her husband. He is buried in the church."
sources: Info table next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet.

title: Gårdby stone Ö 28
description: A well preserved 11-th century runestone, now standing in the cemetery in Gårdby, Öland.
runes: ᚼᛅᚱᚦᚱᚢᚦᚱxᚱᛅᛁᛋᛁxᛋᛏᛅᛁᚾxᚦᛁᚾᛋᛅxᛅᚠᛏᛁᛦxᛋᚢᚾxᛋᛁᚾxᛋᛘᛁᚦxᛏᚱᛅᚴxᚴᚢᚦᛅᚾxᚼᛅᛚᚠᛒᚢᚱᛁᚾxᛒᚱᚢᚦᛁᚱxᛋᛁᚾxᛋᛁᛏᚱxᚴᛅᚱ ᚦᚢᛘ ᛒᚱᛅᚾᛏᚱ ᚱᛁᛏᛁ ᛁᛅᚴᚦᚢ ᚱᛅᚦᛅ ᚴᚼᚾ
explanationAfter: Yes! Swedish translation: "Härtrud reste denna sten efter sin son Smed, en god man. Halvboren, hans broder, sitter i Gårdarike. Brand högg rätt, därför kan du tyda." English: "Hartrud raised this stone after his son Smed, a good man. Halvbor, his brother, is in Gaardarike. Brand (sword?) cut straight, therefore you can decipher". Gårdarike is an old Norse name for the Swedish viking areas in current Russia.
sources: Info table next to the stone, provided by Riksantikvarieambetet.
